div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: GORDON PASHA
div.p: The Entente has brought about some unex. pected results, but none more curious than the publication of "Gordon Pasha," by M. Achille Bioves with the sub-title of "Un Grand Aven. turier du XIXe siècle." It is perhaps natural that the hero's last biographer sh uld dwell at greater length than his predecessors on that religious side of Gordon's character which must seom the most strange to French eyes, and in his chapter on "l'apôtre" he goes at some length into what he calls the "conversion" of Gordon and the mysticism which almost made him an heresiarch. For the rest, he does full justice to his personality, and sums up the problem by describing him as neither a great general nor statesman, and perhaps not even a skilful governor, but one of those scarce beings who sacrifice themselves to the idea of their duty. M. Biovės is also more lenient than may have been expected to the Government which, to our eternal disgrace, first tried to turn Gordon's peculiarities to their own profit, and then basely sacrificed his life to party ad van. tage. Queen Victoria's letter to Miss Gordon leaves no doubt possible on this revelation of the meannesses to which our party system forces otherwise honourable men, and it is not well that we should forget it. For the rest, none of the English Lives of Gordon, brought out with such haste directly after his death, is entirely satisfactory, and many will be glad to read this appreciation of him by an intelligent foreiga writer. It has produced a laudatory review in the "Revue Critique" by the editor, M. Arthur Chuquet, in which he says, among other things, that this Bayard with a tincture of Don Quixote was devoted to the cause of the weak and disinherited.

div.head: KOUBBEH.
div.p: ITS FUTURE AS CAIRO'S IDEAL SUBÚRB.

Mr. Leo Weinthal, F.R.G.8., who is at present staying at the National Hotel, Cairo, has contributed the following interesting article to the "Atrion World," which is one of a series he is publishing in that paper on his previous visit to Egypt:

For the Knabben estate the Khedive has imported the most modern American and English farm machinery, in order to demongʻrate the advantages of tilling with modern appliances. The dairy, kennels, and poultry. yard at Koubbeh are supplied with selected animals and fowls from every olime, and their distinguished owner takes the kernest interest in these departments. For the word people there is a model village, with mos'ne, eohool, and meeting-place--all mort generously supported by his Highness to demonstraté the benefits of order, cleanliness, and community of interest. Amongst other well-organised institutions there is a fire brigade, with English apparatus, whose drilling and tarn-out, I was 2880 red, would be credible anywhere.

KHEDIVE AND HORSE BREEDING. I learned in entally that Eżypt's gifted young ruler maintains from his private parse & special commission to improve horse-breed. ing throughout the onantry, and in further support of this be offers valuable prizes at horse-shows, making pregnant entries for the races during the Cairo BO280D, when it often happens that the Khedivial colours are married to victory by his Highness's native jockey. The Khedive greatly org yg driving, and may nfc be met in the outskirts of Cairo or Alexandria in the smartest of turnouts, holding the reins over a dashing pair, and accompanied by either aide-de-ramp or one of his relatives.

It is very dit salt to dismiss the many de. ligh'fal pastoral an i idyllic scenes of the Koubbeh Estates without referring to the most important recent development in con. the connection with them-viz, the fact of his Highness having given the whole of the ground immediately surrounding ling the Palace gardens, of nearly one thousand agres in exto it, onder option to a power alfa lancial group, with the object of forming an entirely now healthy residential suburb. conveniently close to pity, which is almost certain in a very few years to become one of its m 18t fashi unable and popa. lar quarter.

CAIRO LAND VALUES. Strange to say, comparatively few people in Bagland krow that land in and around Cairo is At present enjoying a remarkable boom, which is steadily expanding and has apparently not yet rosobe i its zenith in prevent valaer. There have been no violent Alictuations; prices have mounted continually; sometimes slowly, 800e. times sharply, bat always ascending. Some Daroels of land in the Rye Moraski - which is bu Oxford Street of E:ypt's hospital, with its oream of world-tamed brazzers-haya ng far apr. passed the prices obtained per foot in the city of London near the Bank of England. The ground on which the British Agency stands was bought by Lord Cromer at 78. per motren not many years ago, and £40 per metre was refused for it last year, whilst certain wig pAdres have been shaking their heads and prophe:ying collapoo and rain-which is geom. accordingly very far distant

Let as calmly face the facts. Cairo is by far the largest town in Africa, where East meets West, and is rapidly becoming the greatest om. poriam of Oriental trade, the real balto-way house and Eastern Exchange for many vala. able and necessary commodities of life, Can This position be nearpod ! Everyone who knows anything of Bgy tian trade to-day will emphatically reply "No." 'Twenty-four years of settled government, the wise fustering of trade and great indogʻrial enterprise to-day by the Khedive and Lord Cromer, Caira's opine position on the Nile in loosest to oh with the Suez Canal and the great coast porte, and its tremendous importance on the numerical key of the 2,000 miles of Nie Valley, emphasise and assare more than ever the splendid future of this unequalled city. Ito population, which is now nearing a round million, shows every sign of increasing, and Egypt's immediato future, if not distarbed by antoward interference, is more brilliant than at any other time in its history.

SALE OF KHEDIVES ESTATE. Thus it is natural that with vast monkeys longonet by years of prosperity there are certain to be great land deals in order to create in borbs for the stench a hospital. For some time past Gh sireh and Rhoda I.lapd have been in great

lemand for villy and private dwellings, and prices--08pecia'ly on the former islap-havo for some an40000ntable reason risen to a giddy height. Will this continue ? Helouan, Meadi, and Heliopolis are now deservedly attracting attention, and our readers require no statistics to convince them that values in these controls have increased substantially within the last two years, to the advantage of property owners and the powernas land agents and companies who are interested in th.m. Quite recently a bomb-bell was thrown into the Cairo property market on receipt of the news of the fortboomingeale of H.H. the Khedive's estate surrounding the Rabb-b Palace to an important group of financiers. No wonder there was a flitter in many doveonter, for Kabab will indeed make o'o the most charming suburbs of Cairo, sita: ated as it is on the northern vim, of which Cairo itself is like the borrow of a gigantic spoon. In sight of the great Mukuttam Hille, close to the desert, yet in itself most fertile and luxurion, K ubb h will be the ideal quarter for those who have decided to make their home in Egypt. The Kbe live's ostate-which I traversed in all directions' 8-consists of nearly four million metres or rich arable land, just far enough from the Nile to have a beautifal day air and enjoying the cool northern breezes f:om the river and from the Mokattam. Exoellapt Government roads traverse the whole proferty, a modern electrio tramway is soon to be constracted right across towards Matarieb and Heliopolis beyond, while the best train service in Egypt brings Koubbeh residents in Cairo vithio the space of twelve minates from no 1,388 than three stationg..

VALUE OF KOUBBEH ESTATE. His Highness the Kbelive drives daily into Cairo from Roubbeb Palace in a little over half ad hoor; and it is well known that his Highness bas never slept at the Abdeen Palace in town. and is never likely to do so while he 040 enjoy the invigorating air of Koubbeh. It is believed that the practical development of this estate will be of immense valaeto permanent residente of the capital, and as soon as bonser, hotels, and abips arise in this truly ideal garden city there will be few people rem sining at night in two. If the ground in Koubbeb sbould be obtainable at a reasonable figore, an onprecedented rasb to this estate may be predioted as soon as those who are forming the company for the development of the estate | come to a decision as to the disposal of the Ind. The next few months should, therefore, | bring this agegaalled Khedivial estate most I prominently before the Egyptian publio. If only

part of the domeroas reports as to leading Kritish, Egyptian, and Continental figanciers combiuing to carry through this grest eastward extension of Cairo are oopfirmed, a vast change should be effecred within the next three years in the apnearance of the country between (airo and Heliopolis. Ground in contral Cairo is still steadily rising, and sales are taking I lace at from £40 to £65 per q ?are metre. At Ileliopolis, quite ton miles out and double the distance to Knabbebi, on the edge of the desert tayond Matarieb, ground is selling at nearly dil por metre. If ground can be obtained at Boabbeb at, say £? to £4 per matre--of phich there is every probability-there is ideed a great fatare of basy activity in store for these beautifal gniet lands which surround tie Khedive's palatial home.

div.head: THE LATE MR. BARKER.
div.p: The funeral of the late Mr. Harry Barker took place yesterday afternoon at 8.30 o'clock, from deceased's house in the Groek quarter. A very large coriège of friends of the deceased followed his mortal remains to the Od British Cemetery at Rosetta-gate, where the burial B irvioo w 18 read by Rev. Canon Ward, assisted by the Rev. Lorgløy. Among those present were the members of the Consular Corps and all the prost prominent residents of Alexandria, The Khedive was represented by T.H.E. M18 18tapha l'a bi Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, and Miralai Hassan Boy Abadi, commandant of the Khalivial Yuoht Mihrgassa, The pall. bearers wore 4.& the Governor of Alex. andria, M. Pierre Gerard, French Cansal (teneral, Mr. Greig. British Vice-Consul, Mr. H F. Dokson, Mr. R. Lang Anderson, and Mr. 11.P. Chataway. The cortège was preceded by a large escort of police, both mounted and frot. There was a large number of beautiful wreaths.
Mrs. Henry Barker and family ask og to tender their thanks to all friends and acquaintances who showed sympathy with them in their bereavement,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.) Ainsi que nous l'avions prévu, le mieux s'accentue et on est en hausse Bar préfané toate 11 côte que nous oldtarons. On est de pilas on plos persuadé en bourse que, gi& •e. au découvert et au bas niveau atteint, apo propriano notable ne peut manquer de se produire dans le courant de la semaine prochaine.

A signaler une amélioration sur la plupart cles gros titres, tels que l'Agricole a 9 3/16, la National Bank a 27 8/4, la Delta Light a 11 1/4, 63 Tramways d'Alexandrie a 184 les Pui.. vi égió +8 et 847 les Dividendes, la Behera a 40 1/4, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier a 813, la Land Bank a 8 7/8, et l'Urbain à 7 7/16 l'ancienne at 6 15/16 la poubelle.
Beaucoup d'autres valeurs d'ordre secon clairs sont aussi en reprise.
L'investment, sar légale les baissiers s'ó. taient acharnés, reprend rapidement à 1 3/16, in bonne tendance..
Beaucoup mieux tonno, l'Union Foncière d'avance a 6 1/16. L'assemblée aura lieu le 27 mars, pour approuver les comptes de l'exercice mit voter le coupon.
On a traité principalement l'Agricole, la National Bank, la Cassa di sconto, la Delta Land, I'Luvestment, les Estates, l'Urbaine, la Building jands et le Crédit Pravo-By Yption.

La tendance générale est bien meilleure. 309000 up de vendeurs qui triomphent ces cours derniers commencent à s'inquiéter et allongent a 80 couvrir. Nous ne pouvons que leur conseiller de le faire au plus vite, avant que la hausse de les entraîne dans une impasse.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN HOSPITAL BALL
div.p: The Fall of tickets for the above-mentioned ball has been almost unprecedented this year and the fangs of the hospital must have been swelled considerably by the proceeds. There have been no danoz of the game description for several seasons, everyone was anxious to show their appreciation of the good work done by the hospital. with the result that lose on a thousand people were present at the ball, and the power of tickets bought was greatly in advance of this pomber. It is no easy matter to make arrangements for such an entertainment; and those of the committee who bad

to face the task may be congratulated on the | very able manner in which they achieved their duties. There is no plane in Cairo 80 suitable for a big ball as the Gbogireb Cibino, and on Thursday night the discovery available corner of the ball-rooms, lounge, cardroom, and adjoining corridors had to be targeted to advantage. It was in every way a brilliant scene, and the beautiful jewels and lovely toilettes in jxta. position to the many uniforms added considerably to the effect. Lady Cromer was present for some time during the early hours of the evening, and most of the well-known resi. dents and visitors were also present, Among those noticed daring the evening ware : - Mr. Machell and Lady Valda Minbell, Lord and Larly Luoeahoroagb, Lady Newborough, Lady Vivian, Mr. and Lady Mariel Beckwith; Lady Helen Gordon. div.head: Caffari's Co-Operative Markets, Ltd
div.p: Le Caire, le Mars 1907. La Société CAFFARI'S CO-OPERATIVE MARKETS LIMITED a l'honneur de porter & la connaissance de l'honorable Colonie Israël lite qu'elle a abordé dans son marché situé rao KA8r-el-Ni', près du Headquarters de l'armée d'Occupation, one section spéciale pour la vente de la meilleure qualité de viandes d'agneau et de la f Cacher 800R le contrôle de surveillants israélo sites nommés spécialement de cet efter, à partir du 10 Mars 1907.

Lo société a obtena on permis de Mr. lDresteor de l'Arikha avec le consentement du Sud Rabbinat pour permettre à ap délégué spécial d'égorger chez elle la volaille suivant les règles religieuses et de contrôler la viand ..

La Société expédie jusqu'à domicile tous les matins les commandes de sa clientèle par l'en. remise des warriors isruě sites nommés spécia. lement pour ce service ; elle expédie également à domicile dans, le obérant de la journée toutes nouvelles commandes, légumes, épicerie, ainsi que tout article de ménage.

La Société espère que l'honorable poblio israélite appréciera l'importance de cette innovation et qu'il faudra bien honorer de sa visite son vaste marché, pour se rendre compte de 84 bonne organisation et de l'excellente qualité de toutes les marchandises mises en vou te.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Egerton of Tatton and tha Daobess of Buckingham have also returned to their old quarters at the Savoy after their short stay in Heloan.
Sir R. and Lady Hamilton Lang left Cairo yesterday for England.
Sir Les'ie and Lady Hantington, with their family are staying at the Savoy; and Sir Benjamin Baker has returned there after his trip to Upper Egypt.

Mr. and Mrs. Cochrane entertained a party at dinner in one of the private dining-rooms of the Savoy Hotel last night. The guests included. ed: Lady Cromer, Major General and Mrs. Bullock M188 Bullock, Comtesse della Sala, Lady Newborough, Col. Cathbert, Lady Blan
he Smiib, Col Granville-Smith, Larly Louisa Mgenie, Col, and Mrs. Drammond Huy, Com. mendatore Malmosi, M-jor Ho-kins, Major Owen, Mrs. Fraser, Mr. Mitchell Innes and Mr. Lyons.

The Savoy Palace Hotel has since its opening become the favourite rendezvous of the blite of Alexandria. Io the crowded dining. room last night we romarked amongst other hosts the following: MM. M. Bolonachi, R. Médasoe, Colacao, Hassan Riassim Boy, Kazim Bey Juhappidis, Bedror, Mx00as Gallio, Moharram Bey, Mastapha Bay, Sacka Salim Bey, Léon Aghion, A. Bolanachi, Agop Bartan Bey, Tagher, etc.
The Judicial Adviser has inspected the priSons and court hooges at Simbel wën, Man 800rab, Damietta, and Me Ballet Kobra.
Mr. James Carrie has arrived at Cairo from Khartoum.
Sand Pasha Zagbloal will visit Dakabin province on a tour of inspection next week.

Mr. and Mrs. Timins, with their two children, are about to become permanent members of the Erg'irh Colony in Cairo. Mrs. Timins in the daughter and grand-daughter of Boglish Colonial Governors. Her father, the late Arthur Barkly, C.M.G., the last English Governor of Heligoland, was ia his tarn the son of Sir Henry Barkly, Governor of Australia, the Cape, and other places.
Col. and Mrs. Sydney Paterson, who spent the best part of last season at the Savoy, are once more back at the same hotel.
M. Serra of the Italian Consulate, in Buenos Ayres, has been appointed first secretary to the Italian Diplomat Agency in Cairo.
H.M. the King of Serbia has conferred the Order of St. Lawi on Pilot Bay, head of the Veterinary Department of the Alexandria Municipality.

Mr. Philip S. Taylor, who has for over ten years been employed on th: editorial staff of the "Egyptian Gazette," has been appointed Assistant Editor of the "African World," London, and leaves for England shortly to take up his new post. He will bear with him our best wishes for his father sacosa.

div.head:
PARIS IN DARKNESS.
EFFECTS OF ELECTRICIANS' STRIKE.

div.p: The pity was in darkness last night owing to a strike of electricians. Only one theatre and ono mosio-ball were opon. Balls and concerts were abandoned. Policemen carrying torches replaced the street lamps. The cafés lit candles. The newspapers cannot be published.
(Reuter)

Thirteen hundred electricians have gone on strike. Soveral quarters of the city are in the dark. 1688. All the theatres are closed. Most of the newspapers, having no motive power, will not be able to appear.
(Paco)

div.p: The Budget Committee of the Reichstag has agreed to votè £9,000 for the building of a Ligation at Addis Ababa.
(Reuter)

div.head:
GERMANY AND MOROCCO.
THE CHIEF OF THE POLICE.

div.p: The "Corriere della Sera," of Milar, pretendo that Germany wishes to bring the Sultan of Morocco to postpone the appointment of Colonel Moller as Chief of the Police in order that a Gurman police corp; might be formed. Everybody knows, however, that it was the German Government who brought about the selection of a Swiss officer for the post. (R.)

The "Vossische Zeitung," in an article, Bay! that the news contained in the telegram from Teheran published in the London "Daily Mail" on the subject of the pretended intention of Germany to occupy the mining territory on the Tarco Persia frontier is ridiculous, and that the story was invented to calampiate Germany.
(Reuter)
The Reichstag bas passed, at the second roading, the credits tor Africa. (Havas

DEVELOPMENT OF TURKEY.
BRITISH CO-OPERATION.

It has been confirmed that an Anglo-Freoch syndicate composed of the Bank of England and the Imperial Ottoman Bank has bought the property of the Constantinople Quay. Company. This fact, coupled with the granting to the Lynch Company, at the instance of the British Embassy, of permission to run three atoamers on the Tigris, is regarded as evidence that British cooperation is promoting the development of Turkey.
(Router)

div.head:
FEMALE SUFFRAGE BILL.
TALKED OUT IN THE COMMONS.

div.p: HOUSE OF COMMONS.—Mr. Dicksop's private Female Suffrage Bill was talked oat. Extraordinary precautions were taken by the police to prevent suffragettes from effecting an entrance to the House.
Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman left the decision to the House bat personally supported the Bill.
(Reuter)

The DJ wager. Empress of Russia has arrived. The Queen and the Prince and Princess of Wales welcomed her at the station. The proceedings were very quiet. Elaborate precautions were taken for the safety of the Empress. (R.,

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Colonel F.U.N. McCracken, D.8.0., Royal | Borkabire Regiment, commanding the 2.d

Battalion, recently in Egypt, will shortly vacate the command on completing his foor pears at its head. He will, it is understood, be succeeded ły M jör R. N. Gamble, D.3.0., second io command of the battalion.
Lieutenant C. J. Marray, coldstream Gaarde, | latterly doing dirty with the Guards' Depot,
Caterbam, has been elected for the appointment of aide de camp to Sir E. Percy Girogard, the new High Commissioner for Northern Nigeria.

None but the most sanguito expect to kno Mr. Haldane's scheme of army reform carried lot in anything like its entirety. The schen e h 18 been pat very nicely by its author, bat it is practically theoretical, and will be found impracticable in many respects. His interference with the Imperial Yeomanry has 010sed much alarm in that force, and if he carries on his avowed intention of red knowing its status to that of the regular forces he will assuredly rain it The Yeomanry are drawn from a very limited class, and socially they are at the blood of the auxiliary forces His proposal to amalgamate the Militia and Volunteers is preposterous 08. The two forces will no more amalgamate than nil and water. They are in many respects diametrically opposed, and the social element invariably counts in these things. At the same time every credit is given to Mr. Haldane for his bold attempt to drag the army oath of the quagmire in which it is involved. At best, it is only an attempt, `` for the military needs of the Empire will never, never be supplied until some kind of "compulsory volunteering"ubraso now well on lors oud-is in force.

Captain H. B. Kelly, who h 48 of late been in command of the first-class battle bip Venerable and was Ang.captain to Vice-Admiral Bridgeman, second in command of the Mediterranean Fleet, has been appointed to succeed Captain Liveson in command of the first class battleship King Edward VII. He will act as fig. captain to Lord Charles Beresford when that officer takes over command of the Channel Fleet.

Captain C. L. Napier, the now officer in charge of the Daval establishment at Sydney, is a very clever and populariffi : r, and he had the advantage of having seen a little bit of the rough side of his profession up the Nile in the early 'eighties. It is over 32 years since he donned the uniform, and his sobre. quent promotions ran-gub-lieutenant, 1881; lieutenant, 1884; commander, 1837, and captain, December, 1902. He was a lieutenant of the battleship Alexsondra in the Sudan War, 1884, and with the Naval Brigade went ap the Nile in the effort to carry relief to gallant Gordon, then immored in Khartoum (medal with clasp, Khedive's star).

div.head: EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY.
div.p: The third ordinary general meeting of shareholders in the Egyptian Investment and Agenoy, Ltd., was held on 28th February at Baltio Honge, Leadenball-street, E. C. Sir Frederick W R. Fryer, K.C.8.1., Chairmau of the company, pre-iding.

The Chairman : Gantlemen,You will, no do'b , agree to allow the report to be taken as read. (Henr, hear.) The results of our second y sur's tradiog have, as I think you will admit, bien eminently satisfactory. Fur the year a.der raport we have mide a net prufit of £13,816 148 101,98 against £8,987 %61 in the previous y ser. In these figures we have not taken into 40000nt the appreciation in valae of our investmtots, wb ch amount", arcording to a recent Valuatior, to or r £30 000.Our expense for the y ar buvo been £5,<33 6s 70, as against £5,669 1. 7d in 1905. You will see that we have soceeded in reducing expenses by £185 154, and have thas redeemed the promise ws made last year to keep oar expenses ti 88 low & limit as is possible cons stently with effizienoy We bave again written off one-third of our preliminary expenses and thiok that vext year we shall be able to write off the remaining one-th rd. We shall tben bave d-charged the whole amount dae oo account of these expen-es. The balance at oredit of profit and loss account is £11,493 5s 10d, in whieb is included £705 78 3d, the balance brought forward from the previous year. The directors propose that the balance be disposed of as follows:-lo payment of a dividend of 20 por 0901., free of income-tax. on the paid-op capital of tbe company (£50 000), £ 0,00 ; to be Orried forward (s hje:t to justment of inome-tax), £1,893 58 10 1-tota £11,893 58 101. Thuge results will, your directors trast, not disappoint your most sanguine expecta: ti 108. I told you at our last meeting that the flotation of the Building Lunds of Egypt, L d., and of the Associated Cotton Ginners of Egypt, Ltd., had just fied our hopes and realised considerable profits. Daring the year the Building Lands of Egypt absorbed the Egyptian Trust and Investment. Ltd., and have increa-ed tbeir capital to £390,000 Their shares are now at 50 per cent. premiom aod represent, perhaps, less than their properties are worib.

EGYPTIAN COTTON CROP. The associated cotton ginners paid for their first season 10 per cent., no' withstanding a very small cotton crop. This year, with a much big. ger cotton crop, a cousiderable increase in profits may be anticipated, and we bave a large interest in an exceedingly profitable industrial concern, two-thirds of wh 18 capital is repre. 89ntel by actaal va'ne iu land property alone. The undertaking of the company is, we consider, one of the filet industrial investments in Ezypt. In December last we offered to the publio the Si li Sulem Estates of Ezypt. Ltd. The company was formed to purchase 14,590 acres of very promising cotton laud at £3x108 per acro. Out of this area 9,000 acres are already leased, thus yielding an ima ediate revenue. The whole of the opleared area is generally good land an i should soon be brooght ander coltivation. With the exceedingly bigh price: prevailing for urban land the fatore in Exypt lies, we tbiuk, wiih agricoltural lando, and our managing director advises that tew properties have before them a greater futore than this estate. We bave one or two other pr jects in hand. which we bope will prowe 80"7098 of pri fit to the onmpany, while we hava done a good business in bll di-counting. Our commerr al brar ch bag wirkud well. It has made a profit of £1 690 9. 51, and we consider that it is likely to do better than this in the fatore. The profi is arrived at after deduction i of ibe manager's commission, and after dae interest has been charged for the funds employed, which is profit to the company. Your directors have continued the policy of keeping their 8989ts in a thoroughly liquid state, and propose to adhere to this policy, which, tboogb perhaps not so startliogly laorative in times of prosperity 88 the policy of lo king op capital in land, will, they are assured, be tborongbly justified whep prices have attaired their full height, and has, at any rate, this merit, that our assets are readi'y realisable.

Our managing director in Egypt reports that Egypt has profi ed daring the past year ly & big cotton crop sold at high prica8, and thongh, perhaps, exaggerate i specalation has been carrie i on in land round Cairo, still the general prosperity of the country is very great and is likely to idorea-e, and the commercial prospects of the coantry are exoellent. NO PRESSING NECESSITY FOR A

RESERVE FUND. Your directors have not deemed it necessary to make any special payment to reserve as yet, although the creation of a reserve is an ohjaot which they have in view, because onr invest: ments are in the natare of a reserve, and with an appreciation faid of over £30,0:0 there is no pressing necessity fır any further reserve. Mr. Mieli, our manager, bag again proved bat our appreciation of his capabilities was correct, and Mr. Hewett has assisted him satisfactorily. Mr. Dreckmeier has been very active in the development of the commercial branob, which we trust will be food to be a very usefal adjnnot to our basine-8. Mr. H. 0. King, our secretary, and our s'aff in Esypt and in Lon. don merit our cordial thanks for their good work and for their devotion to onr intereste, Since the last general meeting Mr. Barré A. H. Goldie has been elected to & beaton the Board, and the sbarebolders are ark. ed to confirm his appointm nt The audie torz, M 33804. I trust that the shareholders will consider that the report of our proceedings for the past year is quite satisfactory, but I shall be quite pleased to answer any questions any shareholders desire to ask./Mr. V. Stawart Cox, one of our di. rectors, I may say, is: unavoidably absent. He fully intended 1 to be present, but I suppose be has been delayed by the fog. I now beg to propose : -'That the directors' report and the annual statement of accounts for the year ended 318t December, 1906, be adopted." | Mr. R. P. Sellon, M.I.E B., seconded the resolution,

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton.

Un de nos amis, qui pourrait faire partie de l'archiconfrérie des baissiers de nature à laquelle on prétend, & tort ou à raison, que nous appartenons, et cela parce qu'il se laisse plus souvent guider par le bon sens qu'entraineur par les courants factices que crée la spéculation, nous disait, pas plus tard que ce soir, que ce n'est pas cette fois que les intéressés à la baisse pourraient se payer notre tête. Et de fait, il a raison, car ce n'est pas avec une réaction de plas d'ap tallari en trois jours que l'on pourrait tourner en vidioule nos probes de modération et nos idées de baisse. A la rigueur même, nous dirions que les roues pour. raient être intervertis, mais cela serait peu charitable de notre part, d'autant plus que nous avons l'habitude de nous montrer mégapoles (on voilà de la modestie !) dans le triomphe et que nos prévisions commencent à peine à se réaliser. Aussi, nous nous limiterons pour aujourd'hui à constater les faits et à ne rien dire qui paisne 'rebatter coox qui nous dénigrent la semaine dernière et qui, probablement, vont chercher à rentrer dans nos bonnes grâces en nous faisant les yeux doux, on peut-être même vous faire l'honneur de nous demander quelle est votre opinion à présent!

Nos lecteurs nous pardonneront ces plaisan. teries, on pea lourdes si l'on veut, mais on brin de bonne humeur est bien permis quand on ressent une certaine satisfaction d'amour. propre, quelque petite qu'elle soit ! Et puis à quoi cela n'aurait-il ?
Ceci dit, passons à la rovne de marché.

Les deux premières journées ont été chander, voire o ême extravagantes, car c'est pour ainsi dire d'emblée avec de la baisse en Amérique et sans le moindre encouragement du côté des exportations, que le Mars a été prié d 235/321! A ce point, tout paraissait feu et flammes et les haussiers semblaient même de plastic connaître de bordes à leurs illo-ions, quand tout.soap est survenue ano circonstance, toute fortuite, qui a tout changé et a renversé tous les callas.

Des demandes pressantes d'argent, pour satisfaire des pertes subies sur les valeurs, n'ayant rencontré qu'un retos catégorique auprès des agences d' xq nelles elles étaient adres. Beos, à moins de liquider la position, ont torce les détenteurs de contrats à se soumettre à cette condition et, comme conséquence les ordres de vente ont commencé à offl ner de tous les côtés. L'importance des réalisations nécessitées par la situation financière ont naturellement provoqué la réaction et c'est dare dare vers 22 1/32 pour le Mars, minimum de la semaine, que nous nous sommes acheminés.

A première vue on reste étonné de la rapidité de la baisse et de son ampleur, mais si l'on plonge à l'exagération da mortement de débat et à l'élévation du niveau adq nel dous sommes op finit vite par reconnaître que ceci n'est que la réponse de cold et peut être même par s'étonner que les choses n'aient pas à pas loin.

Certes tout n'est pas fini avec la vieille récolte, surtout si par malheur nous devons avoir demain une fi iè e dans le genre de celle du premier du mois; mui?, en pong en tenant simplement à ce que nous avons déj 1, nos jobbers et nos gros fumeurs devraient bien comprendre que même 'à ba0-80 a one limite et que si les manipulations réussirent quand il y a do découvert, eiles reste et absolument sans effet et deviennent le plus souvent dangers 04 quand la contrepartie réelle ou représentée par de la marchandise effective. E c'e-t notre 048, et co qoi nous le prouve, c'est, sinon l'in. différence, du moins le peu d'impro grint des vendeurs et la grande anxiété des acheteurs à vouloir reporter le M4r8 por Mai. Il a fallu, de 11/16, monter à 31/32 de tallari pour arriver à obtenir ces tran-forts. Avec ce qui a été payé de Novembre 8 Janvier et ensuite de Janvier à Mars, cela fait un joli denier et nous voudrions bien voir comment le hanger pourra s'en tirer, groot s'il persiste à vouloir al'ar jian'an bont, ca qu'il ne pourrira n'en payánt encore d'autres gros reporta. Rien que l'idée jusqu'où peut aller l'erreur do présentateur nous fait frémir sans oublier qu'il y a encore des gens qui semblent surpri. que malgré la ba osée de 17 talaris an nii oan de 24 personne, ou presque personne parmi les bassiers 'ait gagné de l'argent.

Dox quantité, énorme ont é é reporté 18 ans conditions précitées et cette circonstance a aidé beaucoup d'augmenter le cb ffre des transactions ; d'autres aussi et en grand nombre le seront encore, car les acheteure pour le Mars font défaut et en fait de réceɔtiona, s'il doit y en avoir, il n'y aura que de choses Imiter.

L'intérêt de la vieille récolte va do a su trouver concentré sur le Mai aniquom'n' et bie furt serait ceni qui pourrait prouver que la foule sera fxv irable au banjar. A mine d'un rapprochement ultérieur entre la nonville et l'ancienne récolte et, par d 2*808 la marché, par la baisse de cette lernière, 04 qui fervir changer 188 dipitione de la fil.tare, l'i-800 pour le Mai ne peut être que futile, d'antan plas que beaucoup d'arbitrage tard, comme nous l'avons déjà dit, semblent décidés à ne rien reporter for Juillet.

La tenue de la nouvelle récolte a é.é bax 1 coup plas régalienne et moing agitha q 10 oalla de l'ancienne, et comme ré ultat du jan colo S.S. qui a eu la sar lo Novembre, nong tronvoor le cours de cet- échéance en perts d'un demi tallari sur le maximum de 21 1:/32 atteint à un moment donné, mais restant toujsar3 ayer 1/2 tallari de naage sur le co-are de la Semaine dernière, le prix , ffi ché ce soir étant de 21 1/32. Le déport de Mars N svembra qiri, il y a buit jours à peine, était de talaris 2 3/32 £6 trouve ré lait aujourd'hui à tallari & 1 1/16. Beau profit pour ceux qui ont 80 po décider à acheter le Novembre at vendre le Mars. Dans

div.head: Slaves to Spring Catarrh Restored to Health by Pe-ru-na.
div.p: SPRING THE TIME TO CURE CATARRH.
Pe-ru-na Invigorates Mind and Body.
Hon. Wm. G. Hunter, Ex-remember North Carolina Legislature, writes from the Census Office Building, Washington, D. C., as follows:
"The greatest family medicine ever discovered, in my opinion, which comes from experience as well as observation, is Peruna.

"The most common fiction to humankind is & bad cold. Perung drives it out of doors, wards off catarrh, invigorates and gives fresh strength to mind and body. I give Peri8 my unqualified endorsement."'. Wm. G. Hunte.:.
Takes Peru-na Every Spring.
M188 Tilly Marz, 421 14th St., Milwaukee, Wis., writes:
"I am pleased to endorse Perona, as I found 10 very efficient in ridding my system of a severo cold and catarrhal trouble, after I had tried many other remedies without getting relief.. .

"I took Peruna for two weeks, when I was much better, and in two weeks more I was entirely rid of the cold and catarrh. I shall take it every spring as & tonio, as I found that it made me much better in every way."--Tily Marx.

Miss Lydia Herziger, Grand Recorder of American Daughters of Independence, writes from Neenah, Wis., as follows: ! "I have used Peruna now for four years, each Spring and hall, and it keeps me perfectly well and strong. . "I am able to continue working and do not have to take a three months' rest, as I used to do every year. This is a great comfort to me, as I was not able to afford such a long rest. - "I find that it is a great preventative for colds
and coughs and soon rids the system of all dis. - ease and is an admirable medicine. I can honestly endorse it."--Lydia Herziger.
Mr. James A. Moody, Ex-president Board of Education, Mineral Co., W. Va., writes from 314 Massachusetts Avenue, N. E., Washington, D. C., as follows: : "My family have used Peruna for several
years past with excellent results and I tako pleasure in testifying to its superiority as a remedy for catarrh.
"Every spring that dreaded disease will show up in my family and we always turn instinctively to Perupa to ward it off.
"It has never yet failed, and I never lose an opportunity of recommending it to my friends." -James A. Moody.
Spring Catarrh.
Almost every one has come to believe that spring is a season that brings derangements of the body dependent on blood impurities.

This belief is an old one, is nearly universal, and has arisen, not as the result of the teachings of thy medical fraternity, but has been learned in the bitter Bchool of experience. Nervous Depression.
Depression of the Nervous system at the approach of spring is a fertile source of blood impurities,
There are general lassitude, dull, heavy sensations, continual tired feelings, with irregular appetite, and sometimes loss of sleep.
That Tired Feeling.
That tired feeling, which is the natural result of the depressing effect of warm weather immediately after the Invigorating cold of winter, quickly disappears when Peruna is taken,
The Proper Remedy.

Peruna meets overy indication and proves itself to be perfectly adapted to all their varied peculiarities. Peruna invigorates the system, rejuvenates the feelings, restores the normal appetite and procuies regular sleep.
Do Not Delay.

Get a bottle of Peruns when the first languid feelings make themselves apparent in the spring, Take it according to the directions on the bottle. Continue this treatmont through the first months.of spring.
This course of traatment is no experiment; it is as positive in its results as any fact of science can be.
A Spring Tonic.

Almost everybody needs a tonic in the spring. Something to braco the nerves, invigorate the brain, and cleanse the blood. That Peruna will do this is beyond all question. Everyone who has tried it has had the same experience as
Mrs. Winnifred Power, an artist, who, in a recent lette: from 246 7th St., Port

land, Ore., says: . ! "I am pleased to speak a good word for Peruna, as I found it an excellent tonic and spring medicine and very ef. fective in ridding the system of cold and catarrh. I "About two years ago my system was all run down in the spring and I thought I would try and see if Peruna would be of any assistance in bringing back my health and strength.
"I found that it was splendid and all the medicine th.it I needed. In a little over a month i was well and did not noed to take any more medicine.
"I shall recommend it to every one in Deed of a tonic, and know that I have only to take a few doses of Perana when I take a cold ani! I will soon be over it." -Winnifred Power.
Nature's Assistance.
Spring is the best time to treat catarrh. Nature renews herself every spring. The system is rejuvenated by!

spring weather. This renders medicines more effective. | A short course of Perana, assisted by the balmy air of spring, will sure old, stubborn cases of catarrh that have resisted treatment for years. A Word of Advice. | To those who have been afflicted with chronic catarrh we wish to say that the spring season affords you & splendid opportunity to get rid of your disease,

It may be that you have been affected for several years; you may have tried different remedies. Perhaps you have become discouraged. . Now Is Your Opportunity. | This failure was during the winter months. But now is your opportunity. Nature comes to your assistance at this season.
Just help her a little and she will bring you out of the quagmire in which you have been foundering for so long. Give Nature a little assistance lest hor atrag. gles be in vain.
A Typical Case.
Geo. M. Fillmoro, lato 1st Llent. Srd U.S. Artillery, writes from 909 L St., N. W., Washington, D. O., as follows:
"I brought forward from winter into spring a sickening case of catarrh which was making existence miserable for me, until I was induced to try a bottle of Peruna.

"An immediate improvement gave me hope, if not relief, I kept up taking Perana and it has strengthened and relieved me that I am now confident of a cure. I heartily endorse Peruna for catarrhal affections and as a tonic for their weakening effects."-Geo. M. Fillmore.

A short course of Peruna now will be just in time. During the month of April you will find the strategic time to rid yourself of chronic catarrh, one of the most persistent, stubborn diseases in the whole list of human ailments.
After you have tried it you will say Perana is positively the best spring modicine you have ever used.
A great many years of extensive trials of this remedy in this class of derangements have demonstrated that there are no Failures. Thousands of Testimonials.
Thousands of cases might be quoted in which Peruna has rescued people from the ravages of spring catarrh, and put them on a good, solid foundation of health.

We can give our readers only a slight I glimpse of the vast array of unsolicited endorsements Dr. Hartman is constantly receiving. No other physician in the world has received such a volume of enthusiastic letters of thanks.

If you do not derive prompt and satisfactory results from the use of Peruna, write at once to Dr. Hartman, giving a full statement of your case and he will be pleased to give you his valuable advice gratis.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE
div.p: Qo de fois, lorsque la ballage battait son plein, nous a-t on taxé de pornimime, pour Avoir signalé la voie pérylène 1 n'engage la spéculation. Aujourd'hui que les évènements 10x mêmes nous fournissent ape éclatante jng. lifica:ion, 88 ng pons attarder à d'inutiles commentaires, nous allons 12 ber d'examiner les (20.09 de la dét a le et d'en supporter la durée. Ne así sommes d'autant plus autorisé, à le faire, (que Nous avions prévu depuis longtemp, co ani arrive al jourd'hui.

Pour expliquer la baisse actuelle, au moment où tout le monde s'attendait à la ha0880. il est indispensable de ne pas perdre de vie qu'on 108 tière de spéculation tout s'enchaine. Le Caire, Vendredi 8 Mars 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est remonté de 1/8 & 4 7/8 pour cent. En Stock Exchange le Consolidé anglais & rétrogradé bier de 1/8 a 86 1/4 et l'Unifiés de 1/4 à 102 1/4. La National Bank a perda 1/8 à 27 3/4, l'Agricole 8/8 à 9, la Daïra 3/8 a 16 1/4 et la Delta Light 1/4 a 11 1/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien & encore reculé de 6 franos à 744. La Banque d'Athènes ost rostée io variée a 187.

Notre maroobé ne s'est pas laissé impression: de, ce matin, par les mauvais cours de o'tour transmis de Londres, cours qui 6 siens, il est vrai, l'écho des cours pratiqués ioi. Il ya même un, peu après l'ouverture, de traînée d'ani. mation et des velléités de reprise; mais ces bonnes dispositions n'ont pas tardé à faire place au calme et à quelque pen de loordear. Il n'en apparaît pas moins que les appréhensions exa: gérées de ces jours derniers se sont athéna dos. Les ventos de ralentissent visiblement, notam ment les ventes à découvert qui censorat d'avoir beau jen, la confiance tend à renaître et il n'est pas impossible que des rachats aq8si bien que des achats finissent par déterminer très proobainomont one amélioration sensible.

Dans le compartiment des Borq 198. la NR. tional Bank a mollia 27 5/8.11/16. Bien que ron sogoba a 9 a Londres (var des ordres de vente provenant, dit-on, d'Egypte) l'Agricole s'est maintenue à son prix d'hier, soit 9 1/16 1/8. La Cassa di Sconto a faibli & 269 27'). Le Comptoir Financier est remonté * 7 1/8. La Banque d'Orient s'est raffermie s 134.

Le Crédit Foyer a été délaissé à 748; l'oubli. gation a lots ancienne & repris de francs a 342. La Daïra a été également négligée a 16 1/8 L'Union Foncière a été tonne faiblement à 5 7/8 15/16. Lo Nile Leod a fé hi a 21/4-3/8. L'Allotement a été traité à 8 1/8; sa part a c! taró a 110. L'Enterprise and Development a faibli a 12 1/4.

Les Entreprise S Immobilières et Travaux ont été formément toon 08 entre 6 7/8 et 7; lear part, très long manteau, a avingó de 103 À 123 pour terminer 115. L'Ep-rge Im. mobilière s'est inscrite à 2 1/2; 8a part & passé de 109 à 130-122 L'Express Nile s'est mantona à 4 3/4 et sa part a 130.
Les Jouissances Brux du Clairs ont été négociées entre 278 et 279. L3 Brasserie des Pyramides a faibli à 120 et sa part a 55. Les ciments 86 sont alourdis a 48.
Lo groupe des valeurs h0 elières a été in80 tit. Los Nangovich ont éré délaisvės a 29 at los Egyptian à 12 1/8. Les Upper Egypt ont' faibli a 4 1/8.

Parmi les petites valeera, la Dalta Lind, qui a donné lieu à assez de transactions, a fini en olotore aq même prix que bier, soit 3 15 16 4 Les states sont restés à 2 3/16-1/1; leur par: a décliné à 22 11/16. Los New Egyptian son remontés à 23 sh. 6. Les parts de fondateur Egyptian Land investment and Building ont été demandées aux abords de £ 3.
Nous détachons d'âne correspondance d'A. alexandrie, en date d'hier, le passage suivant :

" Notre maroobé continue à être lourd, avec tendance constante e la réaction. L'opinion pré lomi aita ep B ars; ost que de fortes ventes à découvert contribuent bianco a cette dépression, déterminée en principe par les nouvelles émissions, ainsi que par les nombreuses positions à la hausse reportées avec entremont depuis fin Novembre. Si tel était le cas, c'est-a-dire, si le découvert est aussi considérable qu'on le prétend, il faut s'attendre forcément à one probe et bonne reprise. d'autant plus que bien des titres sur lesquels le parti baissier s'est exercé pourraient diffi ile mot descendre à un niveau plus bas que les prix actuels. Quoi qu'il en soit, la position de la place ont adj.ard'hui passablement nettoyé , et l'on estime généralement que l'améliore jo, commencera à se produire à la fin de la domaine."
C'est aujourd'bui ga's 86 tenne a Londres l'assemblée générale ordinaire de la New Egyptian Co..

Ce meeting aura été probablement intéressant, car la décision prise par le conseil d'administration d'ajourner le paiement d'un dividende a do assorbimento donner lien & ODO d'isolation, ainsi qu'à des explications de la part des administrateurs.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SYRACUSE

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
